properties.Name: Courtyard Meadows
properties.Description:
The site became available when the new Courtyard Apartments were built and it was decided in 2017 to plant the available areas with wildflower seed mixes details of which can be found here.

Over the past number of years, the site has developed well and is rich in X, Y and Z plant species and has an abundance of visiting pollinators including bumblebees, hoverflies and butterflies. For a recent survey of the bumblebees see the following link.

In 2021 some of the meadow was used to house an outdoor gym including a basketball net, exercise equipment and exercise area.

Mowing plan: Cut once a year usually in October. Allowed to grow for the entire season with minimal interference

Herbicide use: 2023- Weed Control on Hard surfaces via Acetic Acid

For recent biodiversity survey results see the following link.

Some nice finds

properties.Name: AstroPitch Meadow
properties.Description:
In 2019 the AstroPitch meadow was developed from a small woodland that had to be cleared to improve visibility for traffic that used the road in both directions. This work was conducted under consultation with a qualified ecologist. A 60m stand of Hawthorne was left after the clearing which now provides excellent forage for hoverflies and solitary bees in Spring and berries for birds.

The site was allowed to naturally regenerate and is now abundant in Dock, Yorkshire fog, Ragwort and Cocksfoot. Ox-Eye Daisy, Cowslip and Yarrow are also abundant and are thought to have established from seed blown in from the Apartment Courtyard Meadow that was planted with native wildflower mixes. For recent surveys of the plants found at this site see the following link.

The site is a stop on the North Campus Biodiversity Loop and the MU Bumblebee monitoring Route. For a recent survey of the bumblebees see the following link.

Mowing plan: Cut roughly every 6 – 8 weeks to a height of 5- 6 inches. Final cut of the meadow occurs in Sept/Oct time.

Some nice finds

properties.Name: Phoenix Meadow & Plaza
properties.Description:
The meadow and plaza at the front of the Phoenix restaurant and sports hall offer a mix of areas managed for biodiversity. these include a small, grassed area which is cut every 6-8 weeks to a height of 5-6 inches. This mowing regime has resulted in the meadow becoming extremely rich in clovers (purple and white) which support a diversity of insects during the summer particular the common carder bee Bombus pascuorum. A number of bee orchids were found on the site in 2019.

The plaza has a number of raised beds that are planted with laurel and lavender which support bees, hoverflies and butterflies and has another raised lawn that has several trees. The raise lawn is mown every 6-8 weeks. The edges of this area were traditionally spayed with glyphosate which exposed the soil on the south facing bank. This encouraged a large aggregation of a number of species of mining bees (Andrena spp). However, with the reduction of chemical pesticide use across the campus the bank has become dominated by grasses and the number of solitary bees and their nests has been greatly reduced. This highlights an important aspect of grounds management, in that the actions that we think are beneficial may have negative consequences. Research is planned to determine sustainable and environmentally friendly ways to expose the bank to promote mining bee colonisations once again.

Mowing plan: Cut roughly every 6 – 8 weeks to a height of 5- 6 inches. Final cut of the meadow occurs in Sept/Oct time.

properties.Name: TSI Frontage
properties.Description:
One of the newest buildings on the campus is the Technology, Society and Innovation (TSI) Building, which opened in 2021. It was the first building at MU where the landscaping was designed using native Irish flora and with biodiversity in mind. The hedging is native Irish hedging and a number of native Irish trees (Scotts pine and silver birch) have been planted around the building.

In addition to a number of ornamental pollinator friendly plant beds, bug hotels and lawn areas which are mown every 6 weeks, the front of the TSI is planted with pollinator friendly bulbs (crocus, allium, daffodils and wood anemone) that flower in early Spring to providing food to early emerging pollinators such as hibernating bumblebees queens.

Mowing plan: Cut roughly every 6 – 8 weeks to a height of 5- 6 inches. Final cut of the meadow occurs in Sept/Oct time.

properties.Name: Edible Garden
properties.Description:
The MU Edible Garden was established formally in 2021 by Dr Patricia Healy-Kettle (Critical Skills and Sustainable Food and Agriculture Working Group Coordinator). Since its inception, the garden has witnessed significant progress and success thanks to the hard work and dedication of the working group, Green Campus, the MU Enviro Soc and the many volunteers and local community of Maynooth who frequent and engage in the garden.

With the aim of bringing staff, students and wider community of Maynooth together to cultivate fresh healthy produce using sustainable principles, the garden has also greatly contributed to Maynooth Green Campus objectives by enhancing biodiversity and local eco-systems (with over twenty new species recently recorded) and fostering sustainable relationships with land, food and nature by connecting food to human health, well-being and environmental sustainability. In addition to the vegetables and fruits that are planted in the raised beds, the garden also has a collection of native Irish apple trees, plums and raspberries and a recently established wildflower strip.

For more details on the Edible Garden and the events that take place there see the following link.

Bees

The edible garden is the last stop on the North Campus Bumblebee monitoring Route and is a hotspot for a diversity of insects and birds. For a recent survey of the bumblebees see the following link
